You can use these rules:
```adblock
||nontonx.com^$replace=/if \(!check\(\)/if(!1/,document
nontonx.com#%#//scriptlet('trusted-replace-node-text', 'script', 'check', '/if \(!check\(\)/g', 'if(!1')
```
Looks it started since several months ago? https://github.com/AdguardTeam/AdguardFilters/commit/9072b1563006f69534c901d5a4d1f4302266435d is normal.

comment.body:
I think first and the last point looks good.
Regarding:
> - If a domain wanted to be added into an existing non-network filter via a PR, it should be added at its tail.

I would add it at the beginning of the rule, regardless of whether it is a direct commit or PR, like it was suggested here - https://github.com/AdguardTeam/AdguardFilters/pull/184595#discussion_r1692914783

Then, Are the following instructions correct?
 - If a domain wanted to be added into an existing non-network filter via direct commit, it should be added at its head.
 - If a domain wanted to be added into an existing non-network filter via a PR, it should be added at its tail.
 - If a domain wanted to be added into an existing network filter regardless of a direct commit OR PR, it should be added at its tail.
I sometimes check such big rules from the older side to find obsolete entries.

>  I'm sure jellizaveta also explained this somewhere.

Was no she, it was ntnguyen1234 and this is the 3rd time I said the same thing: https://github.com/AdguardTeam/AdguardFilters/commit/4cad3d93abfe27b931e34afbff50e2f922110c31#r155810840

I think that the main purpose of doing it that way is that it's easier to spot a difference.
Though I'm using VSCode to check most of the commits in this repository and there is no such a problem, but on GitHub website when there is a lot of domains then whole line is highlighted instead of what was changed - https://github.com/AdguardTeam/AdguardFilters/commit/a0476e86c172fa4cdb04baf12ecfcaecc5bcab34#diff-f1ada99e961d4ff727cacd855a19ff844c71d56e51e181fc66b02bcee5e00699L492

For instance:
```diff
- example.org,domain.com,foo.bar##ads
+ test.com,example.org,domain.com,foo.bar##ads
```
```diff
- ads$script,domain=example.org|domain.com|foo.ba
+ ads$script,domain=example.org|domain.com|foo.ba|test.com
```

For example - https://github.com/AdguardTeam/AdguardFilters/pull/184595#discussion_r1692914783

> to avoid conflicts

> I can just think that it makes solving conflicts easier. 

yep, the second.
It is also easier to maintain identical lists of domains with different types of rules. And especially to find these lists in other files.

comment.body:
### Issue URL (Incorrect Blocking) [https://duckduckgo.com/](https://adguardteam.github.io/AnonymousRedirect/redirect.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Fduckduckgo.com%2F) ### Comment > When having theAdGuard URL Tracking Protection list enabled and searching on DuckDuckGo with a region selected the result doesn't consider the selected region, the language, nor the effective IP of origin (I'm not using a VPN) but forces the engine to show results as if the search was defaulted to United States (Eng) (/ All Regions?). > Even changing region to others, like Germany or France or whatever still shows the same US/Eng based results, the only thing changing is the Wikipedia summary on the side that actually follows the selected region. > Even the correlated searches defaults to US/Eng instead of changing to the corresponding region. > That's the only list enabled or disabled for the test, no other extension active, Firefox on Normal Mode, so nothing else changing except the AdGuard URL Tracking Protection list being enabled or disabled. > Cookies are new, since they get deleted every time I reboot the browser and the results are consistent just by checking or unchecking the list. ### Screenshots
